awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Grounding Institutional Partnerships in Structures for Broader Impacts Design
awd_abstract_narration:
As higher education institutions (HEIs) work to enhance Broader Impacts (BI) efforts, collaborations with informal science education institutions (ISEs) (e.g. science centers, aquaria, zoos) can help them strengthen their impact and reach broader audiences.  This project builds on the successful Portal to the Public (PoP) framework, bringing together the expertise and resources of HEIs and ISEs around the shared mission of engaging public audiences in current STEM research. The project is designed to address several critical needs: (1) Public outreach BI activities are relatively uncommon compared to BI that is focused within the infrastructure of academia; (2) Because collaborations with ISEs are frequently tied to individual Principal Investigators (PIs), there is limited opportunity to build a body of knowledge around the practice of partnering for BI work; and (3) Collaborations are often transient, making it more difficult for universities to view BI on an institutional level in ways that leverage particular institutional assets or strategies and even link investigators from multiple projects.

The specific areas of study are: 
a.  Develop and test a structure for education/outreach BI experience design that addresses a public audience need and meets NSF's BI criterion: The project will create disseminatable tools around the activity design process (including evaluation of learning impacts). By convening cross-disciplinary teams, the project will ensure that experiences will reflect a wide range of expertise and will help meet the needs of multiple stakeholders. These established structures will lower the barrier to entry for PIs who want to do public outreach BI.

b.  Design, test, and study structures for long-term, mutually beneficial HEI-ISE partnerships: The project will build on the proven PoP model to create flexible, disseminatable tools around the development of institutional partnerships at three collaborating HEI-ISE site pairings that consider each institution's resources, constraints and strategic goals, including a cross-institutional and cross-disciplinary Broader Impacts Design (BID) Team structure. Sustained partnerships will support ongoing public engagement with current STEM research.

c.  Anchor the partnership at the HEI with a representative from an office of research support: Research support professionals will be a core part of the BID Team and will help support institutional strategies for aligning BI activities with broader goals around community engagement.

d.  Study the culture of HEI-ISE partnerships, building knowledge about how these institutions can form effective, sustained and mutually beneficial collaborations.

Project partners include Pacific Science Center with the University of Washington, Bothell, WA; University of Wisconsin-Madison with the Wisconsin Institute for Discovery; and the Sciencenter with Cornell University, Ithaca, NY.  In addition, the Center for Research in Lifelong Learning, Oregon State University will oversee the research aspects of the project. The project's primary benefit is the development of more effective mechanisms for HEIs and ISEs to collaborate, that will better enable them to engage their communities in experiences and conversations about current STEM research and innovation.

This project is being funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments.

por.por_cntn:
The Institute for Learning Innovation (ILI) served as the backbone organization for the collaborative research project, Partnerships for Broader Impacts Design. The project aimed to support higher education institutions (such as universities) and informal science education organizations (such as museums, zoos, and science-technology centers), to develop robust partnerships through collaboration around the design of education-based Broader Impacts (BI) experiences. The project built on the successful Portal to the Public (PoP) framework, bringing together the expertise and resources of HEIs and ISEs around the shared mission of engaging public audiences in current STEM research.

Over the course of the project, nine pairs (or trios) of organizations from across the United States worked to establish or strengthen partnerships. An initial cohort of three partnerships convened early in the project and identified a series of possible tools and resources that would help guide their own partnership efforts. These teams identified three pivotal phases of partnership in which specific tools would be useful: ?background for making the case,? i.e., developing internal awareness and support for a potential partnership; ?building a foundation,? i.e., partnered organizations reflecting on their individual and shared assets, and building a foundation for strong communication and collaboration; and ?working within the relationship,? i.e., tools for the partnership work that is focused specifically on Broader Impacts supports. The members of this first cohort drafted versions of tools that they used in their own partnerships, and that might be easily adopted by other partnering organizations. Six additional partnerships then joined the project and tested/refined these tools as they worked to build their own partnership activities. These tools and resources are publicly available as a part of the project?s online resource, here: https://bid.instituteforlearninginnovation.org/tools-resources/.

The nine teams represented a diversity of organization-types and each partnership played out in different, sometimes unexpected ways. The teams also encountered the extraordinary impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, which affected each organization (and partnership) in different ways. This range of experiences did not lend itself easily to generalization, and the team determined that the context and nuance of each partnership is too crucial a part of each partnership?s story to risk it being unacknowledged by a simple set of takeaways. In an effort to convey the full complexity of each partnership experience, the team relied on storytelling, and produced a series of vignettes that describe some of the key events, circumstances, and activities that shaped the partnerships. These stories call into five different categories: BI as a Focal Point of the Partnership; Relationships, Communication, and Recognizing Expertise; Adapting and Thinking Bigger; Durability; and Power Dynamics within the Ecosystem. These stories are available on the project?s online resource, here: https://bid.instituteforlearninginnovation.org/partnership-stories/.

ILI worked in close collaboration with the research team, based at Oregon State University?s STEM Research Center, to share the experiences of each project team through a range of other products, including a series of podcast episodes (https://bid.instituteforlearninginnovation.org/podcast/), mid-way and summative evaluation reports, and a scholarly article with expected publication in 2023.

The team at ILI also produced a chapter for the Handbook of Broader Impacts, which describes the project?s efforts and major takeaways:

Klein, E. and Schatz, D. (2022). Partnership Readiness: A Powerful Opportunity for Informal Science Education Organizations. In (Eds.) VanEgeren, L. and Renoe, S. The Scholarship of Engagement Book Series: Handbook for Broader Impacts (accepted). East Lansing, MI: Michigan State University Press.
